r. All emotions, and that one particularly, were abhorrent to his cold, precise but admirably balanced mind. He was, I

take it, the most perfect reasoning and observing machine that the world has seen,

but as a lover he would have placed himself in a false position. He never spoke of the softer pa

ssions, save with a gibe and a sneer. They were admirable things for the observer--excellent for drawing the veil from men

's motives and actions. But for the trained reasoner to admit such intrusions into his own delicate and finely adjusted temperament was to introduce a distracting factor whic
